title: 104_hr3992
content: The "Medicare Commission Act of 1996" is established. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program is established with 15 members appointed by the President and Senate leaders. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders. Members are selected based on political party affiliation and congressional membership limits. Appointments must be made within 3 months of the Act's enactment, and members serve for the Commission's duration with vacancies filled promptly. The National Commission on the Long-Term Solvency of the Medicare Program consists of 15 members appointed by various leaders. Vacancies in the Commission do not affect its powers and are filled promptly. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed, with meetings called by the Chairman. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and a Chairman is selected from among the members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF THE COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with reviewing analyses of Medicare trust funds, identifying threats to their solvency, analyzing potential solutions, and providing recommendations to ensure financial integrity and provision of health benefits under the Medicare Program. The Commission will review the solvency of the Medicare trust funds, which include the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Medical Insurance Trust Fund. They will submit a report to the President and Congress within 12 months and develop legislation for consideration by Senate and House leaders. The Commission will develop legislation for the long-term solvency of the Medicare trust funds, to be introduced in the Senate and House of Representatives within 3 months for privileged consideration if not voted upon. The legislation introduced in the House and Senate must be voted upon within 3 months of its introduction, with privileged consideration if not voted upon. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted upon within 3 months, with privileged consideration if not voted upon. Legislation introduced in the Senate must be voted upon within 3 months, with privileged consideration if not voted upon. If not voted on within 3 months, a joint resolution endorsing recommendations in a report must be considered. The Commission established by the Act has the power to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and use postal services. Additionally, the Act addresses personnel matters related to the Commission. The Commission members who are federal government officers or employees serve without additional compensation. Private citizens on the Commission also serve without pay, but they are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Commission members, including federal government officers and private citizens, serve without additional compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Chairman can appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws, with support services provided by the Secretary of Health and Human Services. The Chairman of the Commission can appoint an executive director and set their compensation without following civil service laws. Federal government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting its report. Expenses will be covered by funds available to the Secretary of Health and Human Services.
